quizzes.question: What are the two Boolean values in Python?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Booleans[/h1]

Another type in Python is the [b]Boolean[/b] type. There are two Boolean values: [b]True[/b] and [b]False[/b].
They can be created by comparing values, for instance by using the equal operator [b]==[/b]. [code format="py" codeId="294"]>>> my_boolean = [b]True[/b]
>>> my_boolean
[b]True[/b]

>>> 2 == 3
[b]False[/b]
>>> "hello" == "hello"
[b]True[/b][/code]
[note]Be careful not to confuse [b]assignment[/b] (one[b] [/b]equals sign) with [b]comparison[/b] (two[b] [/b]equals signs).[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
>>> 7 != 8
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

Another comparison operator, the [b]not equal[/b] operator ([b]!=[/b]), evaluates to [b]True [/b]if the items being compared aren't equal, and [b]False [/b]if they are.[code format="py" codeId="295"]>>> 1 != 1
[b]False[/b]
>>> "eleven" != "seven"
[b]True[/b]
>>> 2 != 10
[b]True[/b][/code]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
>>> 7 > 7.0
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

Python also has operators that determine whether one number (float or integer) is greater than or smaller than another. These operators are > and < respectively.[code format="py" codeId="296"]>>> 7 > 5
[b]True[/b]
>>> 10 < 10
[b]False[/b][/code]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
>>> 8.7 <= 8.70
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

The greater than or equal to, and smaller than or equal to operators are >= and <=.
They are the same as the strict greater than and smaller than operators, except that they return [b]True[/b] when comparing equal numbers. [code format="py" codeId="297"]>>> 7 <= 8
[b]True[/b]
>>> 9 >= 9.0
[b]True[/b][/code]
[note]Greater than and smaller than operators can also be used to compare strings [b]lexicographically [/b](the alphabetical order of words is based on the alphabetical order of their component letters).[/note]
